comments.body: it's unclear what this is when there was not conversion happening? Will it be nil? Or the equal value? Same below.

we will always populate it, but old apiservers will not (obviously), so someone writing a webhook using our go types to work against pre-1.15 apiservers can not assume they'll get a value here. we can strengthen the spec in v1 admissionreview

added a TODO to clarify in AdmissionReview v1 docs
And that the call must not have side effects.

+1, what about something also indicating that a value of DryRun false doesn't guarantee that the object will be persisted, so any side effects should have a reconciliation mechanism, or is that redundant because it's already somewhere in the webhook documentation?
It should be documented, but feel free to state it again here if you think it makes it clearer.
This is violating our API convention that the empty value of an optional field has to be `nil`. But I guess we don't care anymore since there are so many violations in our code base.

This is reflecting the optionality of what was already in the API. I agree we need to come up with a consistent story on what and when we are going to do about our large base of optional/non-pointer fields.
"If that is the case, this method will return the empty string." ...so, it's not really optional, is it?
Note on this that the server is free to omit this value when returning a response to a caller.  That avoids a plugin having to serialize the object back, and the cost to decode from the response.
Note on this that the server is free to omit this value when returning a response to a caller.  That avoids a plugin having to serialize the object back, and the cost to decode from the response.
I think we could just do the same thing at the `Spec` level because this is a non-mutating AC.  Right?

Not about mutating or not, just because of performance.  The mutating field would be returned in status.  That way a caller only has to check allowed, and optionally a response, if and only if it was changed.
